item.title: Coronavirus: Latest data shows vaccine reduces transmission - Hancock
item.description: Matt Hancock says hospital admissions are falling more sharply than the first wave of the pandemic.

item.title: Exeter house fire: Girl, 4, and couple die
item.description: Police call it a "tragic incident" and say no-one is being sought in connection with the fire.

item.title: Jo Whiley: It's been the worst week of our lives as Frances struggles with Covid
item.description: The DJ says her sister Frances, who has a learning disability and diabetes, is "fighting for her life" with Covid.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Right' to delay contract transparency in pandemic, says Hancock
item.description: The health secretary defends his team after a court rules he acted unlawfully during the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: Christian group fined £10k for Bulwell car park meet
item.description: Police say the site is "evidently not a place of worship" but the church plans to contest the fine.

item.title: US plane engine fire: 'I just knew something was wrong'
item.description: Video shows the engine, which failed shortly after take-off, burning and missing its casing.

item.title: Oil spill disfigures Israel's coast
item.description: Israel warns residents to avoid beaches as it tries to track the ship behind the pollution.

item.title: Coronavirus: Medical regulator investigates £30m Covid contract firm
item.description: Hinpack, which makes test tubes, is run by the former landlord of a pub near Matt Hancock's old home.

item.title: Malcolm X family demands reopening of murder investigation
item.description: A letter from an ex-policeman alleges that New York police and the FBI conspired in the 1965 murder.

item.title: Boys, 15, charged after car stolen with two young children inside
item.description: Two teenagers are charged with kidnap after a car was stolen with boys, aged two and four, inside.

item.title: Seven die in Nigerian Air Force Abuja plane crash
item.description: The military plane crashed short of the runway in the capital Abuja, after reporting engine failure.

item.title: Cambridge moonflower: Team 'overwhelmed' by global response
item.description: Having thousands watch a rare cactus bloom online leaves the team that planted it "overwhelmed".

item.title: Lockdown review: What are the risks of schools, pubs and shops reopening?
item.description: Lockdown could slowly be lifted soon but what are the risks associated with relaxing certain restrictions?

item.title: Jasmine Harrison on being youngest solo female to row Atlantic Ocean
item.description: Jasmine Harrison, 21, on becoming the youngest woman to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: The homemade special effects livening up lockdown
item.description: Peter Quinn moved from Northern Ireland to America to work in the VFX industry over a decade ago.

item.title: Kangaroo Island dunnart: Saving a bushfire-ravaged marsupial
item.description: Already critically endangered, Australia's Kangaroo Island dunnart has lost most of its habitat.

item.title: Painting every sunrise teaches Leeds artist to 'live presently'
item.description: Tom Newhouse aims to capture every sunrise in 2021 in oils to create "one grand display of colour".

item.title: May Willis: 'I'm almost 111 and make the most of what I've got'
item.description: May Willis, from Bexhill, credits her long life to no smoking, no alcohol - and lots of chocolate.

item.title: Covid: 'Each one of these people mattered'
item.description: Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg is using art to show the "depth and breadth" of Covid's US death toll.

item.title: ICYMI: An ice carousel, a wallaby and a mammoth tooth
item.description: Here are some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Don't ask me which vaccine is best, please
item.description: Dr John Wright says he's often asked which vaccine is best, but the answer is it's too early to say.

item.title: How Trump offered Kim a ride on Air Force One
item.description: A new BBC series shows how threats of nuclear war against North Korea gave way to a Trump-Kim bromance.

item.title: Are streaming algorithms really damaging film?
item.description: Director Martin Scorsese says streaming algorithms demean cinema and treat viewers as consumers.

item.title: Singapore vending machines now dispense salmon, crab and even cacti
item.description: The city state has a dizzying array of vending machines, dispensing everything from cacti to pizza.

item.title: How European businesses are adapting to Brexit
item.description: Companies doing business between Europe and the UK talk to the BBC about the impact of the new rules.

item.title: Covid-19: Which countries in Africa are administering vaccines?
item.description: Some African nations have just begun vaccination programmes, but many have yet to start.

item.title: The petrol that was poisoning children
item.description: How a successful campaign led to the banning of lead in petrol in the UK

item.title: Netflix and Anna Delvey: The race to secure the story of New York's 'fake heiress'
item.description: How Anna Sorokin's life rights became hot property.

item.title: Early Sterling goal gives leaders Man City victory at Arsenal
item.description: Manchester City extend their winning run to 18 games as they continue their impressive march towards the Premier League title with victory at Arsenal.

item.title: West Ham 'haven't hit top gear yet' despite beating Spurs to go fourth
item.description: West Ham move into the top four of the Premier League with a narrow victory over Tottenham that increases the pressure on Spurs manager Jose Mourinho.

item.title: Rangers 10 points from title after easing past Dundee Utd
item.description: Steven Gerrard will not get "carried away too soon" despite victory over Dundee United meaning Rangers need 10 points to win the Scottish Premiership.

item.title: Hastings and Bayliss in Scotland squad for Paris - but Redpath out injured
item.description: Adam Hastings is back in the Scotland squad for the Six Nations game with France while Josh Bayliss gets his first call up.

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: More people have been added to the clinically extremely vulnerable list in England. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Has the NHS got enough of the right PPE?
item.description: Who needs it - and does the UK health service have the right kit?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 16 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK, so when might you get one?

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Is the Covid vaccine safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Covid: What are the UK's lockdown rules and when will they end?
item.description: People across the country have been urged to "double down" and stick to the lockdown rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Vaccine passports: Do I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The growing number of people vaccinated may be able to gain more freedoms in the future.

item.title: Covid: When will schools reopen?
item.description: Boris Johnson is expected to focus on the re-opening of schools is his "roadmap" for easing lockdown.

item.title: Covax: How will Covid vaccines be shared around the world?
item.description: A scheme to distribute Covid-19 vaccines globally is under way. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of a new variant of Covid-19.

item.title: What is a challenge trial and why do we need them?
item.description: Some volunteers in the UK will be deliberately infected with coronavirus in a "challenge trial".

item.title: Covid: Claims vaccinations harm fertility unfounded
item.description: Social-media posts - some described as "scare stories" - are based on misunderstandings, experts say.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Covid: How will we know if the vaccine is working?
item.description: Deaths are falling faster for the over-80s - but does that mean the vaccine is working?

item.title: Surviving rape: 'I'd watch TV and start feeling sick'
item.description: Martha was raped by a man she had trusted. She explains what it's been like trying to overcome this.

item.title: Foot-and-mouth outbreak: Looking back at the crisis after 20 years
item.description: A vet recalls how farmers wept as she told them that their animals were infected with the disease.

item.title: Cannabis found by off-duty Essex police officer during house viewing
item.description: The off-duty officer was visiting the property with an estate agent when they looked in the garage.

item.title: Brian Johnson says AC/DC album is tribute to 'spiritual leader' Malcolm Young
item.description: Singer Brian Johnson says the band wanted to make Scottish founder Malcolm Young proud with their new album.
